newsitem.title: LEBANON: FIVE KILLED IN UNIFIL HELICOPTER CRASH IN LEBANON.
newsitem.headline: FIVE KILLED IN UNIFIL HELICOPTER CRASH IN LEBANON.

text.p: Five United Nations peacekeepers were killed when their helicopter crashed in south Lebanon on Wednesday, a U.N. Interim Force in Lebanon (UNIFIL) spokesman said.
The spokesman said the cause of the crash was not immediately clear. The helicopter crashed inside Israel's occupation zone in south Lebanon.
"Five were killed. The helicopter went down in the Bint Jbeil area. We are firing flares to help with the recovery work," the spokesman told Reuters.
"We are headed towards the crash site. We are a few kilometers away," he said.
UNIFIL did not yet know the nationalities of those killed, the spokesman said, "but the pilot and copilot were obviously Italian because all of our pilots and co-pilots are Italian".
"It will probably take until the morning until we find out further details," he added.
The 4,488-member UNIFIL force was established in 1978 to restore the Lebanese government's authority over the southern part of the country after an Israeli incursion against Palestinian guerrillas.

After Israel withdrew its troops following a 1982 invasion, it retained a so-called security zone along the Lebanese side of the border, aided by its allies of the South Lebanon Army (SLA) militia, to block attacks against northern Israel.
The U.N. force consists of contingents from Fiji, Finland, France, Ghana, Ireland, Italy, Nepal, Norway and Poland.
